docs.lead_paragraph: Birth control pills do not protect women from ovarian cancer if the women carry certain breast cancer genes, researchers are reporting in Thursday's New England Journal of Medicine. Until now, doctors knew that women taking the pill were less likely than other women to develop ovarian tumors, which occur in about 23,000 American women each year and lead to roughly 14,000 deaths.

headline.main: Pill May Not Be Cancer Guard, Study Says

docs.abstract: Researchers report that birth control pills do not protect women from ovarian cancer if women carry certain breast cancer genes; study reported in New England Journal of Medicine (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: IT is said that the truth will set you free, but for Connie Moutis, it was truth serum. Ms. Moutis, 69, of Union, N.J., was grounded her entire life by aviophobia (fear of flying) so acute that she couldn't even look at an airplane or go near an airport. Every year her husband would fly by himself to Greece to visit his relatives, and she was afraid that she would die before she ever got to meet them.
docs.abstract: Article on Dr Balada Prasad, anesthesiologist in Mount Vernon, NY, who has been treating phobias and addictions using sodium pentothal (truth serum); patients and Dr Prasad comment; photos (M)
